section.title: Proficiency Testing and Interoperability Overview
section.para: Laboratory proficiency testing (PT) participation is a requirement for performance of clinical testing under the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988 (CLIA 88) to provide an important comparison and objective assessment of lab staff competencies, specimen handling, equipment functionality, and results reporting. PT is an external quality and accuracy assessment process that tests unknown specimens from a PT provider to ensure accurate laboratory results. After submitting test results, the laboratories receive data that compares their performance with that of other laboratories in their peer group (e.g., other laboratories that performed the same test on the same instrument and reagent platforms). The interoperability issues that make direct transmission results from the performing laboratory to quality organizations such as PT vendors challenging are very similar to the issues that laboratories face when they receive results from external laboratories through Health Information Exchanges (HIE) and HL7 interfaces. Individual laboratories have always utilized their own local test codes, tests names, normal range values, and formats of test results and associated units. To compensate for this lack of standardization, PT vendors have had to implement a system of custom codes to standardize the representation of required data elements across result submissions from laboratories to allow them to perform their function of assessing the accuracy of results and comparing the performance of the subscriber laboratory to their peer groups of other laboratories utilizing the same instrumentation and reagents. Like HIE laboratory result transmission, being able to correctly interpret PT tests and determine equivalence of test results often requires more information than is currently available with most test result transmissions. Method information such as instrument and reagent information are not currently able to be captured or transmitted through Laboratory Information System (LIS) and Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems. The methodology information is not transmitted with the result and must be “married up” within the PT vendor information system when the PT result is received. Methodology information is stored in the PT vendor system and is often derived from historical reporting and must be manually changed by the subscriber laboratory whenever there is a change.

section.title: Current State Architecture
section.para: When looking at possible future state architectures for the transfer of data between quality organizations it is important to examine the current state architecture of the solutions in place today. After further exploration, it becomes evident that it is quite different from that of a traditional interface utilized in a laboratory. Specifically, it is different in the way that the data is transferred, and how the data needs to be encoded before it gets to its ultimate destination. Please see below for a graphic of what the current architecture looks like for submitting results to a quality organization.

While this narrative is meant to demonstrate a possible future state architecture for the transfer of data within quality organizations, part of the intention of this analysis is to take a close look at how data is currently transmitted. This document will also show how proficiency testing is currently disconnected from the laboratory interface ecosystem. It will look at some options that could be used to move the needle towards implementing standards, systems processes, and technical frameworks across the clinical and quality ecosystems that can better harmonize the approach to data transmission.

The CAP currently employs two methods for direct transmission of PT results from a subscriber laboratory. One method utilizes a specially designed PT driver, embedded in a widely utilized Instrument Manager Middleware, and the other employs a Cloud-based Hub solution. When a PT sample is received by the subscriber laboratory from the PT vendor, laboratory personnel must place an order into the LIS system to register the PT specimen. This involves utilizing fields in the LIS system such as “Patient Name” to provide necessary information for the PT workflow, often using the name or code of the PT survey being conducted, as the specimen "Patient Name" entry. The PT specimen must then be analyzed in the same manner as any patient sample, for the indicated test.

In the case of the instrument middleware transmission method, PT results generated by the instrument are automatically sent to the Instrument Manager, where the PT results are recognized using the PT survey code, translated, and reformatted by the specially designed PT driver. This process of translation and reformatting includes applying the custom codes developed by the PT vendor to identify the PT test in a standardized format regardless of local code and local test name conventions.

For users of the Cloud-based Hub direct transmission method, laboratory personnel run a report in the LIS to extract and send PT results, using the PT survey code, to a folder on the laboratory’s network. The PT results are transferred to a Cloud-based Hub by agent software monitoring the folder. The PT results are translated and reformatted like the Instrument Manager Middleware method, with PT vendor developed custom codes applied, to identify data elements in a standardized format.

The final step is the same for both the Instrument Manager Middleware and Cloud-based Hub and the formatted result file is transmitted to the PT vendor system where the PT results are automatically populated into the appropriate fields of the result form. Laboratory personnel can review results and to make changes such as correcting methodology prior to final submission.
Current State Transmission Architectures

section.title: Proficiency Testing Coding
section.para: Although the use of custom codes by PT vendors solves some of the interoperability issues by allowing for aggregation of PT results from multiple laboratories regardless of local name and local code conventions, the PT transmission process is disconnected from the healthcare ecosystem because the custom codes utilized by PT vendors are never incorporated into LIS and EHR systems and are never transmitted outside of the PT direct transmission workflow. In addition, each PT vendor has developed their own set of custom codes which allows for interoperability of results only within their system

Replacing PT developed vendor custom codes with existing standard ontology codes and incorporating these codes into the LIS and EHR system would theoretically allow for interoperability beyond PT results, including for more efficient downstream use of real patient data for public health and analytics once implemented in the clinical domain. While this may sound like an easy proposition, many barriers stand in the way of widespread implementation. First, there must be an authoritative source for standardized codes that is easily accessible to laboratories. The objective of the Laboratory Interoperability Data Repository (LIDR) is to digitally represent laboratory tests using standard ontologies to fully define the test characteristics to allow for accurate interpretation and equivalence determination and a shared understanding of the data as it moves across the healthcare ecosystem. Incorporation of the standard codes into LIS and EHR systems should be as automated as possible with the codes easily accessible and transparent to laboratory personnel for ease of maintenance. Further development and investment of resources needs to occur with some of the coding systems to allow for new codes to be published at the speed of business to accommodate the need of all data consumers. Lastly, the healthcare ecosystem infrastructure must be updated to support this paradigm shift to ensure that all necessary codes needed to digitally represent laboratory tests are able to be captured and seamlessly transmitted throughout the healthcare ecosystem without loss of information and meaning.

section.title: Future State Architecture
section.para: Outlined below are some design ideas for how to transition from the current state architecture into a solution that is more closely aligned with how patient data is transmitted, which can then be modeled and utilized across various clinical, quality, and public health use-cases. The diagram below is meant to be a high-level architecture diagram of how technology and interfaces can be utilized, to help quality organizations consume data that has been encoded with LIDR. Its purpose is to consume individual tests/results coming from laboratories, as well as bulk tests/results to be able to provide feedback to the individual submitting laboratory and to the LIDR Repository.

Currently, incorrect mapping of a subscriber laboratory test to custom code used by the PT vendor could result in the test being graded against the wrong criteria and the laboratory failing the challenge for that test. To avoid that situation, there is functionality and systems in place that allow for subscriber laboratories to evaluate whether the custom code mapping in the Instrument Manager Middleware and Cloud-based Hub solutions are accurate, prior to submitting survey results. Similar tools that could evaluate the standard coding provided by LIDR in the LIS and EHR would serve an important quality assurance function that would not only ensure that subscriber laboratories do not fail PT surveys due to mapping errors but would also improve the interoperability of transmitted patient data and the quality of real-work data.

In addition, quality organizations could provide important feedback to the administrators of LIDR on any significant gaps in available coding for specific areas of laboratory testing (e.g., microbiology or molecular pathology). Harmonization of coding between vendors would be essential as PT vendors need to be able to aggregate similar tests across vendor platforms, as well as grading against specific vendor peer groups. PT vendors utilizing LIDR codes in place of custom codes could therefore provide important feedback on any conflicting coding between vendors for similar tests.

The intent is that technology and workflows like the one proposed in this diagram will eliminate the need for custom mapping. Currently quality organizations and their customers often must do some type of mapping to accept incoming tests/results from a laboratory into the quality organization. With this process the goal is to have semantic interoperability between the laboratory and the quality organization, and hopefully expand interoperability to include patient results throughout the healthcare ecosystem.
High Level LIDR Encoded Data Flow

In breaking this process down, some key points, assumptions, and areas that need further evaluation will be provided. In anticipation of socializing and analyzing this diagram, conversation will be initiated that will lead to thoughtful improvements as well as a more detailed picture of the specific workflow and technology that would be needed to stand up a proof of concept.

section.title: Future Considerations
section.para: Below are some highlights, narrative, assumptions, and areas that need further consideration for this process:

section.title: Laboratory Information System (LIS)
section.para: The first critical part of this workflow is when the LIDR is applied to the LIS. At this point we have assumed (but will need to clarify through the project) that the LIDR would be applied in one of three ways:

listitem.para: A real-time interface. As the LIDR is updated it flows into the LIS
Third-party load. Either through a connection to a third-party database or an import into the LIS. Similar concept to the way pharmacy loads medications into the EMR
Update the LIS manually. This would involve LIS staff manually updating the compendium

section.para: Here are some things requiring evaluation as part of this process:

listitem.para: Do all the data elements that are part of LIDR exist in the LIS?
If not, is there a need to partner with LIS vendors to add fields?
What are the pros and cons of these options? For example, is a benefit to one of the automated solutions above that there are less errors in the downstream part of this process?

section.title: Interface
section.para: If this data is transported over an interface, the standard used will need to be evaluated. It is known that most laboratories are using HL7v2 for the traditional interfaces to reference labs and public health agencies. In addition, the FHIR standard has gained traction and looks to be increasingly required to implement for specified use-cases under the 21st Century Cures Act. There will be a need to evaluate how these different standards may be able to help the transport of quality data.

The interface solution that is ultimately utilized will need to have the flexibility to send standard data, send data elements that may not exist in the standard currently, and potentially string data together depending on what the need is from the “Validate and Normalize” process below.

section.title: Validate and Normalize
section.para: The quality organization will evaluate the incoming data and consume that structured data. Determination will need to be made if that is one piece of data or a concatenated string of data. In the current state it is a 1:1 mapping based on test code. It will need to be evaluated if a single piece of data, such as the LOINC code would suffice, or if a concatenation of multiple data elements together could be utilized and could be sent as a string of unique data. Evaluation of the concatenated data string would need to occur, to determine where concatenation would happen during the transfer of data from the LIS to the “Validate and Normalize” part of the workflow.

section.title: Valid
section.para: Once the above work is completed, the data can then pass through the error management part of the workflow. If the data is “Valid” it would be passed through for final consumption into the quality organizations ecosystem and be used to complete the business process (e.g., PT, reporting, analytics).

section.title: Error Management
section.para: If it does not pass the “Valid” check then it would need to go through the error management process and feedback would need to be provided. Feedback would be provided in the following ways:

listitem.para: A single lab has a missing or incorrect piece of information, but the receiving party feels that the LIDR file is correct. In this case feedback would be given to the individual lab.
The receiving party receive codes and realize that the same instrument from multiple laboratories is feeding data that is not correct. Feedback would be provided to the LIDR repository.
This process is meant to take bulk tests/results and process them. In this case if any issues are found that feedback would be provided to the LIDR repository
